title: How to Make Rock Cakes

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 350°F (180°C).
steps.description: On gas stoves with gas marks for heat, this is usually around 6.

steps.headline: Chop the butter into small cubes.
steps.description: The butter should be roughly centimeter large cubes. This will make it easier to mix in later on. Chill your butter in the refrigerator or freezer for 20 to 30 minutes beforehand so it is easier to manage.

steps.headline: Pour 1 3/4 cups flour and 4 oz butter into mixing bowl.
steps.description: When measuring flour, use a sift or stir the flour quickly with a fork to break up large chunks and get an accurate measurement.

steps.headline: Cut butter into flour until it looks like fine bread crumbs.
steps.description: Toss the chilled butter to coat it in flour. Then take two knives and literally cut into the mixture with crisscrossing motions. Think of cutting an "X" into the butter and flour with the two knives. The butter should be about the size of peas when you are done. You can also lightly massage the butter and flower with your fingertips, or you can use a pastry blender, which looks like 4 to 5 wire arches attached to a handle.

steps.headline: Add sugar, baking powder, and fruit.
steps.description: Mix together the ingredients so that they are evenly distributed, and then stop. Over mixing can lead to starchy or tough cakes.

steps.headline: Beat egg and vanilla essence in a separate bowl and add to flour mixture.
steps.description: Mix together to form a stiff dough. If you are having trouble adding mixing the dough, add 1-2 tablespoons of milk to thin it out.

steps.headline: Grease a large baking tray.
steps.description: Using either cooking spray or a small pat of butter, grease a baking tray to prevent the rock cakes from sticking. You can also cut a piece of parchment paper and use it to line the baking tray.

steps.headline: Heap spoonfuls of dough 2-3 inches apart on the baking tray.
steps.description: Using a spoon, drop a dollop of dough onto the greases baking tray. Remember–these are rock cakes, so they don't have to be pretty to look like rocks.

steps.headline: Bake for 20 to 25 minutes at 350°F (180°C).
steps.description: Check the cakes occasionally to make sure they are not burning. They are done when the outsides are firm and golden brown.

steps.headline: Add cinnamon and nutmeg for a spiced rock cake.
steps.description: Perfect with tea or coffee, simply add 1 teaspoon cinnamon and 1/2 teaspoon nutmeg to the flour for a tasty spiced pastry. You could also consider a 1/2 teaspoon of allspice, cloves, or orange zest to suit your preferences.

steps.headline: Add 1 cup of oats for classic British rock cakes.
steps.description: Simply mix in the oats after cutting the butter and flour. You may need to add an extra 1/2 cup of milk in order to blend the oats in with the dough, as they will soak up the liquid quickly.

steps.headline: Add chopped apples and cinnamon for apple cakes.
steps.description: This simple, scone-like treat is easy to make. Simply add the apples and cinnamon in place of the dried fruit.

steps.headline: Add shredded coconut for Jamaican rock cakes.
steps.description: Tasting a bit like unsweetened coconut macaroons, adding coconut takes your rock cakes to the next level. Mix the coconut in with the dried fruit.

steps.headline: Substitute chocolate for dried fruit for sweeter cakes.
steps.description: Some people think that everything is better with chocolate, and they will find compelling evidence in chocolate rock cakes. Simply add an equal amount of semi-sweet chocolate chips when you would add dried fruit.

steps.headline: Add lemon juice or orange juice for a moist citrus rock cake.
steps.description: Squeeze half a lemon or add a splash of orange juice in place of milk to add a little tang to your rock cake. You can also add 1/2 cup lemon curd for sweet, moist cakes that are similar to scones. Grate 1 to 2 teaspoons of lemon or orange rind into the dough for a more pronounced citrus flavor.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 190ºC.
steps.description: Prepare a baking tray by lining with baking paper or a silicone sheet.

steps.headline: Place the flour and butter into the mixing bowl.
steps.description: Rub together until well combined.

steps.headline: Add the sugar.
steps.description: Mix through. Then add the mixed fruit and mix in as well.

steps.headline: Add the eggs gradually, stirring in as each bit is added.
steps.description: Mix well. If the mixture seems too doughy or stiff at this stage, you can add a little milk or water to loosen it a bit.

steps.headline: Use a tablespoon of rock cake batter to form each cake on the baking tray.
steps.description: These will spread, so leave room between each one added. To finish off, you can sprinkle a little sugar on top of each one, but this is optional.

steps.headline: Place in the preheated oven to bake.
steps.description: Bake for 20 to 25 minutes or until the appear golden in colour.

steps.headline: Remove from the oven.
steps.description: Transfer to a wire cooling rack and allow to cool. These are always best eaten on the same day they are baked. If not eaten, keep in an airtight container but be warned, they lose texture and flavour quickly after baking day.

text: Rock Cakes Preheat the oven to 350°F (180°C). On gas stoves with gas marks for heat, this is usually around 6. Chop the butter into small cubes. The butter should be roughly centimeter large cubes. This will make it easier to mix in later on. Chill your butter in the refrigerator or freezer for 20 to 30 minutes beforehand so it is easier to manage. Pour 1 3/4 cups flour and 4 oz butter into mixing bowl. When measuring flour, use a sift or stir the flour quickly with a fork to break up large chunks and get an accurate measurement. Cut butter into flour until it looks like fine bread crumbs. Toss the chilled butter to coat it in flour. Then take two knives and literally cut into the mixture with crisscrossing motions. Think of cutting an "X" into the butter and flour with the two knives. The butter should be about the size of peas when you are done. You can also lightly massage the butter and flower with your fingertips, or you can use a pastry blender, which looks like 4 to 5 wire arches attached to a handle. Add sugar, baking powder, and fruit. Mix together the ingredients so that they are evenly distributed, and then stop. Over mixing can lead to starchy or tough cakes. Beat egg and vanilla essence in a separate bowl and add to flour mixture. Mix together to form a stiff dough. If you are having trouble adding mixing the dough, add 1-2 tablespoons of milk to thin it out. Grease a large baking tray. Using either cooking spray or a small pat of butter, grease a baking tray to prevent the rock cakes from sticking. You can also cut a piece of parchment paper and use it to line the baking tray. Heap spoonfuls of dough 2-3 inches apart on the baking tray. Using a spoon, drop a dollop of dough onto the greases baking tray. Remember–these are rock cakes, so they don't have to be pretty to look like rocks. Bake for 20 to 25 minutes at 350°F (180°C). Check the cakes occasionally to make sure they are not burning. They are done when the outsides are firm and golden brown. Variations Add cinnamon and nutmeg for a spiced rock cake. Perfect with tea or coffee, simply add 1 teaspoon cinnamon and 1/2 teaspoon nutmeg to the flour for a tasty spiced pastry. You could also consider a 1/2 teaspoon of allspice, cloves, or orange zest to suit your preferences. Add 1 cup of oats for classic British rock cakes. Simply mix in the oats after cutting the butter and flour. You may need to add an extra 1/2 cup of milk in order to blend the oats in with the dough, as they will soak up the liquid quickly. Add chopped apples and cinnamon for apple cakes. This simple, scone-like treat is easy to make. Simply add the apples and cinnamon in place of the dried fruit. Add shredded coconut for Jamaican rock cakes. Tasting a bit like unsweetened coconut macaroons, adding coconut takes your rock cakes to the next level. Mix the coconut in with the dried fruit. Substitute chocolate for dried fruit for sweeter cakes. Some people think that everything is better with chocolate, and they will find compelling evidence in chocolate rock cakes. Simply add an equal amount of semi-sweet chocolate chips when you would add dried fruit. Add lemon juice or orange juice for a moist citrus rock cake. Squeeze half a lemon or add a splash of orange juice in place of milk to add a little tang to your rock cake. You can also add 1/2 cup lemon curd for sweet, moist cakes that are similar to scones. Grate 1 to 2 teaspoons of lemon or orange rind into the dough for a more pronounced citrus flavor. Simple Rock Cakes Preheat the oven to 190ºC. Prepare a baking tray by lining with baking paper or a silicone sheet. Place the flour and butter into the mixing bowl. Rub together until well combined. Add the sugar. Mix through. Then add the mixed fruit and mix in as well. Add the eggs gradually, stirring in as each bit is added. Mix well. If the mixture seems too doughy or stiff at this stage, you can add a little milk or water to loosen it a bit. Use a tablespoon of rock cake batter to form each cake on the baking tray. These will spread, so leave room between each one added. To finish off, you can sprinkle a little sugar on top of each one, but this is optional. Place in the preheated oven to bake. Bake for 20 to 25 minutes or until the appear golden in colour. Remove from the oven. Transfer to a wire cooling rack and allow to cool. These are always best eaten on the same day they are baked. If not eaten, keep in an airtight container but be warned, they lose texture and flavour quickly after baking day.
sentences: Rock Cakes Preheat the oven to 350°F (180°C).
On gas stoves with gas marks for heat, this is usually around 6.
Chop the butter into small cubes.
The butter should be roughly centimeter large cubes.
This will make it easier to mix in later on.
Chill your butter in the refrigerator or freezer for 20 to 30 minutes beforehand so it is easier to manage.
Pour 1 3/4 cups flour and 4 oz butter into mixing bowl.
When measuring flour, use a sift or stir the flour quickly with a fork to break up large chunks and get an accurate measurement.
Cut butter into flour until it looks like fine bread crumbs.
Toss the chilled butter to coat it in flour.
Then take two knives and literally cut into the mixture with crisscrossing motions.
Think of cutting an "X" into the butter and flour with the two knives.
The butter should be about the size of peas when you are done.
You can also lightly massage the butter and flower with your fingertips, or you can use a pastry blender, which looks like 4 to 5 wire arches attached to a handle.
Add sugar, baking powder, and fruit.
Mix together the ingredients so that they are evenly distributed, and then stop.
Over mixing can lead to starchy or tough cakes.
Beat egg and vanilla essence in a separate bowl and add to flour mixture.
Mix together to form a stiff dough.
If you are having trouble adding mixing the dough, add 1-2 tablespoons of milk to thin it out.
Grease a large baking tray.
Using either cooking spray or a small pat of butter, grease a baking tray to prevent the rock cakes from sticking.
You can also cut a piece of parchment paper and use it to line the baking tray.
Heap spoonfuls of dough 2-3 inches apart on the baking tray.
Using a spoon, drop a dollop of dough onto the greases baking tray.
Remember–these are rock cakes, so they don't have to be pretty to look like rocks.
Bake for 20 to 25 minutes at 350°F (180°C).
Check the cakes occasionally to make sure they are not burning.
They are done when the outsides are firm and golden brown.
Variations Add cinnamon and nutmeg for a spiced rock cake.
Perfect with tea or coffee, simply add 1 teaspoon cinnamon and 1/2 teaspoon nutmeg to the flour for a tasty spiced pastry.
You could also consider a 1/2 teaspoon of allspice, cloves, or orange zest to suit your preferences.
Add 1 cup of oats for classic British rock cakes.
Simply mix in the oats after cutting the butter and flour.
You may need to add an extra 1/2 cup of milk in order to blend the oats in with the dough, as they will soak up the liquid quickly.
Add chopped apples and cinnamon for apple cakes.
This simple, scone-like treat is easy to make.
Simply add the apples and cinnamon in place of the dried fruit.
Add shredded coconut for Jamaican rock cakes.
Tasting a bit like unsweetened coconut macaroons, adding coconut takes your rock cakes to the next level.
Mix the coconut in with the dried fruit.
Substitute chocolate for dried fruit for sweeter cakes.
Some people think that everything is better with chocolate, and they will find compelling evidence in chocolate rock cakes.
Simply add an equal amount of semi-sweet chocolate chips when you would add dried fruit.
Add lemon juice or orange juice for a moist citrus rock cake.
Squeeze half a lemon or add a splash of orange juice in place of milk to add a little tang to your rock cake.
You can also add 1/2 cup lemon curd for sweet, moist cakes that are similar to scones.
Grate 1 to 2 teaspoons of lemon or orange rind into the dough for a more pronounced citrus flavor.
Simple Rock Cakes Preheat the oven to 190ºC.
Prepare a baking tray by lining with baking paper or a silicone sheet.
Place the flour and butter into the mixing bowl.
Rub together until well combined.
Add the sugar.
Mix through.
Then add the mixed fruit and mix in as well.
Add the eggs gradually, stirring in as each bit is added.
Mix well.
If the mixture seems too doughy or stiff at this stage, you can add a little milk or water to loosen it a bit.
Use a tablespoon of rock cake batter to form each cake on the baking tray.
These will spread, so leave room between each one added.
To finish off, you can sprinkle a little sugar on top of each one, but this is optional.
Place in the preheated oven to bake.
Bake for 20 to 25 minutes or until the appear golden in colour.
Remove from the oven.
Transfer to a wire cooling rack and allow to cool.
These are always best eaten on the same day they are baked.
If not eaten, keep in an airtight container but be warned, they lose texture and flavour quickly after baking day.
